article.para: There are a wide variety of office applications available for Xubuntu that allow you to create documents, spreadsheets, presentations, graphics, and even to design publications.
Some of these applications are included by default in Xubuntu while others can be easily installed using Synaptic.

sect1.title: GNOME Office
sect1.para: The default office suite in Xubuntu is GNOME Office. The applications in this suite are generally lighter and faster than the programs in the OpenOffice.org suite, and have fewer features as a result. But this may be exactly what you want. The suite has excellent compatibility with other major Office suites, such as Microsoft Office.
The GNOME Office suite includes the following software:

note.para: Only a subset of these applications are installed in Xubuntu by default, but the rest can easily be installed separately using Synaptic. Currently Abiword, Gnumeric and The GIMP are installed by default in Xubuntu. To use the other applications you will need to install them manually (see Add Applications).

sect1.para: To install applications within the GNOME Office suite:

step.para: The following packages from the Universe repository are part of the GNOME Office suite (see Add Applications). You may choose to install all of them for the full office suite, or choose only the ones you need.

The Office applications can then be found in the menu at

sect1.title: OpenOffice.org Suite
sect1.para: Also available in Xubuntu is the OpenOffice.org office suite. Compatible with other major office suites including Microsoft Windows, OpenOffice.org is free to download, use, and distribute. This office suite is not installed by default in Xubuntu. It can easily be installed though using Synaptic. See Add Applications for instructions on how to do this.
The OpenOffice.org suite includes the following applications:

listitem.para: Writer – a word processor you can use for anything from writing a quick letter to producing an entire book. It can be started with &openoffice-writer;.

Spreadsheet – a powerful spreadsheet with all the tools you need to calculate, analyse, and present your data in numerical reports or sizzling graphics. It can be started with &openoffice-spreadsheet;
Presentation – the fastest, most powerful way to create effective multimedia presentations. It can be started with &openoffice-presentation;
Draw – lets you produce everything from simple diagrams to dynamic 3D illustrations. It can be started from inside another Openoffice.org program.
Database – lets you manipulate databases seamlessly. Create and modify tables, forms, queries, and reports, all from within OpenOffice.org. It can be started with &openoffice-base;

Mathematical function creator – lets you create mathematical equations with a graphic user interface or by directly typing your formulas into the equation editor. It can be started from inside another Openoffice.org program.

note.para: For more details about the OpenOffice.org suite, visit OpenOffice.org homepage.

sect1.title: GnuCash Accounting Application
sect1.para: GnuCash is a program to manage your personal or business finances. GnuCash lets you track bank accounts, stocks, income and expenses. As quick and intuitive as a checkbook register, it is based on professional accounting principles to ensure balanced books and accurate reports.

note.para: For more information visit the GnuCash Web site

step.para: Install the gnucash package from the Universe repository (see Add Applications).
To start GnuCash, choose &gnucash;.

sect1.title: Scribus Desktop Publishing Application
sect1.para: Scribus is a professional desktop publishing program. For more information, see the Scribus website.

step.para: Install the scribus package (see Add Applications).
To install additional templates, install the scribus-template package from the Universe repository (see Add Applications).

note.para: You will need to use Synaptic Package Manager to install this package

step.para: To start Scribus, choose &scribus;.

sect1.title: Sending documents to other people
sect1.para: Sometimes, you may wish to send a document to someone who is using a different operating system, such as Microsoft Windows. They may use an office application which is not capable of understanding the file formats used by the office suites available in Xubuntu. This can cause confusion if they find that they are unable to open the document you sent.
The solution to this problem is to save the document in a format which they can use before you send it.

caution.para: By saving your file in a different format, the way the document looks could be changed slightly. This is due to small differences between the way different programs read file formats. You may receive a warning message about this when trying to save a document in another format; it should be safe to press Yes, which will save the file in the new format you chose.

sect1.para: The instructions for OpenOffice.org are as follows:

step.para: Open the document you wish to send using OpenOffice.org.
Press FileSave As... and then press File type. A list of available file types should appear.
Select an appropriate file type. For example, if you are sending your file to a user of Microsoft Word, the file type Microsoft Word 97/2000/XP is a sensible choice.
Select a location to save the file in, then press Save.
Send the file as normal, for example by attaching it to an email by pressing FileSendDocument as E-mail....

note.para: A quick way of sending your document by email and in the Microsoft Word format from the OpenOffice.org Word Processor is to press FileSendE-mail as Microsoft Word.... Equivalent commands are available for the other applications in the OpenOffice.org suite, such as E-mail as Microsoft Excel... in OpenOffice.org Spreadsheet.

sect1.para: Instructions for Abiword and Gnumeric (GNOME Office word processor and spreadsheet):

step.para: Open the document you wish to send using Abiword (documents) or Gnumeric (spreadsheets).
Choose FileSave As.... Then select an appropriate file type from the list marked Save file as type.
Select a location to save the file, then press OK.
You can now share the new file with users of other office products.

sect1.title: Finding clipart to use in documents
sect1.para: A piece of clipart is a picture or drawing used to illustrate a document. Follow the instructions below to install and use a selection of clipart in OpenOffice.org:

step.para: Install the openclipart-openoffice.org package from the Universe repository (see Add Applications).

caution.para: The openclipart-openoffice.org package is very large, so it could take a long time to download and install.

step.para: Open an OpenOffice.org application and press ToolsGallery. A list of available clipart should appear.
Browse the clipart until you find an item that you would like to use. To insert the item, either drag it into the document or right-click the item and press InsertCopy.

sect1.para: Abiword can also include clipart and other images in documents. To do this follow these instructions:

step.para: From the menu bar select InsertPicture
Locate the image you would like to include in your document. Select it, then press OK

note.para: To find additional clipart that can be freely used in your documents, try OpenClipart.org.
